awd_titl_txt: Toward the Establishment of a Reciprocal Knowledge Exchange Community for Extending BPC Capacity and Impact
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Center for Women and Information Technology (NCWIT) is running a series of "Knowledge Exchange Workshops" to build capacity in the Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) community for broadening participation in computing (BPC). The workshops will bring together a range of stakeholders -- CISE Principal Investigators (PIs), department chairs, the CISE BPC Alliances, and other national organizations that focus on inclusion in science and engineering -- to support the PI community in planning for meaningful broadening activities as introduced in the recently issued Dear Colleague Letter (NSF 17-110).

CISE has long supported work in broadening participation BPC with targeted programs and specific requirements in some solicitations. The pilot discussed in the Dear Colleague Letter aims to expand that work by encouraging involvement of the larger PI community. The workshops will promote a "Knowledge Exchange," giving the PIs and department chairs the chance to discuss their current BPC efforts, needs and concerns, and giving the Alliances and the other organizations the chance to describe their existing resources and programs, and the communities they serve. The expected outcomes include a wider understanding of the BPC efforts currently underway, the creation of new partnerships that will increase the availability of community efforts that individual PIs could join in fulfilling their own BPC goals, and facilitation of the development of departmental BPC plans that provide new opportunities for faculty involvement. These workshops will lead to an expansion of the community of CISE change leaders poised to implement reform efforts.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past years, NSF has invested in Broadening Participation in Computing (BPC) Alliances to address the underrepresentation of women, Hispanics, Black/African Americans, Native Americans, and persons with disabilities. Using a social science research basis and rigorous evaluation of programs, the Alliances have created many resources and programs that can advance the diversity of the professional and scientific computing workforce if applied more broadly in the community. Transfer of the Alliances organizational knowledge/approaches to computing faculty has high leverage and payoff in terms of accelerating broad impact. 

The National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT) originally proposed to plan and convene two workshops at which CISE PIs and BPC Alliances would come together to exchange knowledge about BPC practices and the contexts in which they're implemented. Establishing this "reciprocal knowledge exchange" community was intended to drive sustainability and innovative thinking, possibly laying the groundwork for a new organization of BPC Alliances.

One workshop was planned and delivered on March 13-14 of 2018; 95 people from universities and K-12 non-profits attended. Attendees shared knowledge of how local contexts limit or enable action, their interests, and their ideas for greater collaboration among organizations.  Formal evaluation was conducted and results published.  Funds from this grant were used to cover meeting preparation and participant travel costs.

In June 2018, NCWIT also used funding from this grant to assist in organizing and evaluating a CISE Chairs meeting held June 7-8 2018, as well as a meeting held at CRA Snowbird in July 2018.  These meetings led to the formation of the formal BPCnet effort, https://bpcnet.org, currently led by CRA.  NCWIT participates in this moving forward effort as a BPC Alliance.  

Funds remaining in 2019 were initially intended to be spent on additional in-person conventings about BPCnet.  Such convenings were disrupted throughout the pandemic years.  Hence, NSF approved spending the remaining funds on virtual events focused on the original intent of the grant for CISE PIs through the NCWIT Academic Alliance and BPCnet. Virtual convenings covered training about NCWIT resources available through BPCnet (March of 2021 and April of 2023).  

In addition, in 2022, eighteen NCWIT Academic Alliance faculty from three post-secondary institutions participated in NCWIT's Academic Tech Inclusion Journey (TIJ) training. After the training, they piloted the TIJ in their departments. The objective was to test the revised online Academic Tech Inclusion Journey in real- world circumstances and gather formative evaluation data to set direction for next- iteration revisions and refinements. The TIJ is based on a research based academic change model which is uploaded to this report.

Specific outcomes from this funding include: 

  • Initial organizational formation of what has become BPCnet and participation in the formal BPCnet effort
  • Providing NSF CISE PIs with NCWIT-specific opportunities they could take part in to fulfill their BPC proposal requirement.
  • Making sure the communication of those opportunities is clear and concise  (e.g., this ACM SIGCSE conference publication - https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3287324.3287332) 
  • Establish a competent, helpful liaison to work with potential PIs and NCWIT program staff and publicize opportunities (see uploaded image for a poster presented at NSF INCLUDES in 2019)
